attribution: Library and University Collections, The University of Edinburgh

canvases.label: A Compleat Theory of the Scots Highland Bagpipe, Inside front cover

metadata.value: A Compleat Theory of the Scots Highland Bagpipe
metadata.label: Title

metadata.value: 2 of 38. Joseph MacDonald was trained in the highlands of Scotland as a piper from a young age, but in 1760, he left Scotland for a job with the East India Company. MacDonald wrote this manuscript in his cabin on the sea voyage to India. In 1763, MacDonald died of a tropical fever. It wasn't until 1794 that the manuscript resurfaced, being sent back to Joseph's brother, Patrick, who worked to have it published in 1803. The manuscript represents the first written account of bagpipe music theory. Although much of the theory is still practised today, some of the techniques described are notable for their unique style and the incredible dexterity required. David Laing has included a note on the inside front cover stating that he purchased this manuscript in 1833 from Lord Eldin's sale.
metadata.label: Description

metadata.value: A Compleat Theory of the Scots Highland Bagpipe

It wasn't until 1794 that the manuscript resurfaced, being sent back to Joseph's brother, Patrick, who worked to have it published in 1803. The manuscript represents the first written account of bagpipe music theory. Although much of the theory is still practised today, some of the techniques described are notable for their unique style and the incredible dexterity required. David Laing has included a note on the inside front cover stating that he purchased this manuscript in 1833 from Lord Eldin's sale.
metadata.label: Description
